Science suggests that there are certain moments

We use a group of brain regions 
that's collectively called

the Executive Attention Network using them,

Your brain is at rest. You're not focused on

Creative thinking is thought to involve 
the interplay of both of these networks,

a kind of teamwork between spontaneous thinking 
and cognitive control. The default mode network

is involved in generating ideas, while the 
Executive Attention Network is important

in selecting ideas, working

aha moment. And there's one occasion where 
our brains use both of these networks.

The moment that we're drifting off to sleep 
the moment between wakefulness and sleep has

long been suspected to hold something special. 
The inventor, Thomas Edison, would allegedly

taste the twilight moments between being awake and 
being asleep. It said that Edison would sleep in a

chair with a tray and two bowls. When he drifted 
off to sleep, he'd drop the balls in the tray.

They'd make a loud noise that would jolt him 
awake, and he'd write down his ideas before he

forgot. Fast forward to today, and a new study 
used this technique to investigate if the very

first sleep stage called and one offers the 
right conditions for insight and creativity.

Participants were given a task where 
they had to identify a hidden pattern.

Then they were seated in a reclining 
chair holding a metal drink bottle,

which they would drop if they drifted off into 
the first sleep stage. If the bottle fell,

the participants were asked to report what 
they were thinking just before they let go.

The researchers found that those who drifted into 
anyone for at least 15 seconds with three times as

likely to identify a hidden role to complete the 
task compared to those who had remained awake.

The findings support the fact that the interplay 
of those brain networks in the first stage of

sleep can lead to insight. So I wanted to
